prs.l: in some dialects & in other dialects informally

dt: {bc}product or result of an action or process
{bc}something used in an action or process
{bc}action or process connected with (a specified thing)
{bc}something connected with, consisting of, or used in making (a specified thing)

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}-ung, -ing{/it}, suffix forming nouns from verbs; akin to Old High German {it}-ung{/it}, suffix forming nouns from verbs
shortdef: action or process : instance of an action or process
product or result of an action or process —often in plural
something used in an action or process

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}-ing, -ung{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}-ing{/it} one of a (specified) kind

dt: used to form the present participle
and sometimes to form an adjective resembling a present participle but not derived from a verb

pt: Though the pronunciation of {it}-ing{/it} with the consonant \n\, misleadingly referred to as "dropping the {it}g{/it}," is often deprecated, this pronunciation is frequently heard. It is not known for certain why the Middle English present participle ending {it}-ende{/it} was replaced by {it}-ing.{/it} Analogy with the earlier noun suffix {it}-ing{/it} probably had something to do with it. In early Modern English, present participles were regularly formed with {it}-ing{/it} pronounced \iŋg\ (as can still be heard in a few dialects) and later \iŋ\. Evidence also shows that some speakers used \in\ and by the 18th century this pronunciation became widespread. Though teachers (with some success) campaigned against it, \in\ remained a feature of the speech of many of the best speakers in Britain and the U.S. well into the 20th century. It has by now lost its respectability, at least when attention is drawn to it, but throughout the U.S. it persists largely unnoticed, and in some dialects it predominates over \iŋ\.

shortdef: —used to form the present participle and sometimes to form an adjective resembling a present participle but not derived from a verb

dt: {bc}to cancel or obliterate with a series of {it}x{/it}'s

shortdef: to cancel or obliterate with a series of x's —usually used with out

dt: {bc}to draw an x or a series of x's through (something) to show that it is wrong or not wanted

dt.t: One line of the text had been {it}x-ed out{/it}.

shortdef: to draw an x or a series of x's through (something) to show that it is wrong or not wanted
